doc.ContractDescription: THE PROPOSAL IS A TWO-YEAR PLAN FOR A MASTERS THESIS RESEARCH AND A THIRD YEAR FOR THE INITIAL STAGE OF A PH.D. STUDY AT UMASS LOWELL. THE NASA MODERN-ERA RETROSPECTIVE ANALYSIS FOR RESEARCH AND APPLICATION (MERRA) DATA, COMBINED WITH OTHER DATASETS, WILL BE USED FOR A LONG-TERM (1979-PRESENT) DAILY WEATHER TYPING ANALYSIS FOR THE NORTHEAST US (HEREAFTER NOTED BY NE). THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED WITH THE HELP OF SOME PROGRAMMING IN MAINLY MATLAB WITH OTHER PROGRAMS BEING USED WHEN NECESSARY. THE PURPOSE IS FIRST TO ANALYZE DAILY WEATHER TYPES (WTS) IN THE SPRING, SUMMER AND FALL SEASONS IN THE NE, THEN TO COMBINE WITH THE WINTER WTS WHICH WERE CALCULATED IN A PREVIOUS MASTER THESIS (ROLLER 2014, UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF PROF. QIAN), TO STUDY THE SPATIAL PATTERN AND FREQUENCY OF WTS AND THE SEASONAL TRANSITION OF WTS IN THE NE. THE FIRST TASK IS TO CALCULATE WTS IN THE SPRING, SUMMER AND FALL. SINCE THE K-MEANS CLUSTERING METHOD HAS ALREADY BEEN DEVELOPED FOR THE WINTER SEASON, A SIMILAR METHOD WILL BE USED TO CLASSIFY WTS IN THE REMAINING THREE SEASONS. FOR EACH WT, WE WILL ANALYZE ITS MULTI-SCALE CHARACTERISTICS INCLUDING SPATIAL PATTERN OF WINDS, PRECIPITATION AND TEMPERATURE AND FREQUENCY OF OCCURRENCE, DIURNAL CYCLES OF WINDS AND PRECIPITATION, AND PERSISTENCE OR PROGRESSION FROM ONE WT TO ANOTHER. AFTER UNDERSTANDING WTS IN THE FOUR SEASONS, WE WILL CONDUCT A SECOND TASK TO EXAMINE THE TRANSITION FROM SEASON TO SEASON IN TERMS OF THE DAILY WTS. WE WILL EXAMINE THE SIMILARITIES AND DIFFERENCES OF THE WTS BETWEEN SEASONS, AND HOW THE WTS VARY DURING THE ONSET AND DEMISE STAGE OF A SEASON. THE THIRD TASK WILL BE ON CLIMATE TELECONNECTION BETWEEN THE WTS AND LARGE-SCALE REMOTE CLIMATE FACTORS SUCH AS NORTH ATLANTIC OSCILLATION (NAO), ARCTIC OSCILLATION (AO), PACIFIC NORTH AMERICAN (PNA) PATTERN, EL NINO-SOUTHERN OSCILLATION (ENSO), ETC., IN THE SPRING, SUMMER AND FALL, AS WAS DONE IN THE WINTER (ROLLER 2014). UNDERSTANDING OF THE WTS IN ALL FOUR SEASONS WILL GIVE US A HOLISTIC VIEW OF WEATHER AND CLIMATE IN THE NE THROUGHOUT THE WHOLE YEAR. WE BELIEVE THAT THE PROPOSED STUDY WILL PROVIDE NEW KNOWLEDGE IN THE LINKAGE BETWEEN WEATHER AND CLIMATE IN THE NE. WE ALSO EXPECT TO APPLY THE RESULTS OF THIS WEATHER-WITHIN-CLIMATE STUDY IN THE NE ON SOCIETAL AND ECONOMIC APPLICATIONS AFTER THE COMPLETION OF THIS THREE-YEAR RESEARCH. THIS RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE A BETTER OUTLOOK TO THE CLIMATOLOGY OF THE NORTHEAST WITH RESPECT TO PATTERNS OF WTS OVER THE PAST FEW DECADES. THIS CAN HELP DETERMINE WHETHER THERE HAS BEEN CLIMATE VARIABILITY IN THE NORTHEAST, THE CAUSE OF WHICH, IF ANY, CAN BE FURTHER STUDIED.

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF IN PHASE I BUSEK MATURED THE DESIGN OF AN EXISTING 15-KW LABORATORY THRUSTER. MAGNETIC MODELING WAS PERFORMED TO GENERATE A CIRCUIT INCORPORATING MAGNETIC SHIELDING. EROSION MODELING PREDICTS EXTREMELY LONG LIFETIME AND HIGH THROUGHPUT. A DETAILED MECHANICAL DESIGN OF THE THRUSTER RESULTED IN AN OVERALL ASSEMBLY WITH SPECIFIC MASS<3KG/KW. MODAL, DYNAMIC AND THERMAL ANALYSES WERE PERFORMED TO CALCULATE RESONANCE FREQUENCIES, MODE SHAPES, STRESS AND FATIGUE VALUES AND TEMPERATURE LIMITS. EXPERIMENTS USING THE EXISTING LABORATORY THRUSTER EVALUATED A MODIFIED ANODE/GAS DISTRIBUTOR AND A B-FIELD DISTRIBUTION REPRESENTATIVE OF THE PROPOSED MAGNETIC SHIELDED CONFIGURATION. PERFORMANCE RESULTS SUGGEST SIMILAR EFFICIENCY AND PERFORMANCE AS THE BASELINE THRUSTER. VISUAL OBSERVATION OF THE PLUME ILLUSTRATED THE CHARACTERISTICS OF MAGNETIC SHIELDING WERE ACHIEVED. IN PHASE II BUSEK WILL COMPLETE THE DETAILED DESIGN OF THE THRUSTER AND A CENTER MOUNTED HOLLOW CATHODE. A PROTOTYPE UNIT WILL BE FABRICATED AND PERFORMANCE TESTED INCLUDED LIMITED DURATION TESTING AT BUSEK. DEPENDING ON FACILITY AVAILABILITY THE THRUSTER WILL INDEPENDENTLY TESTED AT GRC. BUSEK WILL HOLD A MRR AND CDR THEN FABRICATE, ASSEMBLE, AND FULLY TEST A QUALIFICATION MODEL THRUSTER/CATHODE TO RAISE THE MATURITY TO TRL 6. THE THRUSTER WILL BE DELIVERED TO NASA FOR EXTENDED DURATION TESTING TO COMPLETE THE QUALIFICATION.

doc.ContractDescription: BOSTON CHILDREN'S MUSEUM (BCM), IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE SMITHSONIAN ASTROPHYSICAL OBSERVATORY (SAO), PROPOSES TO CREATE OUR SKY, A SERIES OF EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AND RESOURCES THAT INSPIRE AN APPRECIATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF EARTH AND SPACE SCIENCE (ESS) IN A DIVERSE POPULATION OF CHILDREN AGES 3 - 10 AND THEIR PARENTS, CAREGIVERS AND EDUCATORS. OUR SKY FOCUSES ON INTERDISCIPLINARY EXPLORATIONS OF OBJECTS AND PHENOMENA VISIBLE IN THE SKY, ENCOURAGING PARTICIPANTS TO LOOK UP NOT ONLY WHEN THEY VISIT THE MUSEUM, BUT ALSO IN THEIR EVERYDAY LIVES. THE PROJECT WILL HIGHLIGHT HOW INTERWOVEN PHENOMENA IN THE SKY ARE NOT ONLY WITH SCIENCE, BUT WITH OUR CULTURES, OUR ARTS, OUR HISTORIES AND OUR UNDERSTANDINGS OF THE WORLD AROUND US. OBJECTS AND OBSERVATIONS OF OUR SKY HAVE INSPIRED EVERY AREA OF HUMAN THINKING AND CREATIVITY - FROM EARLY BELIEFS AND CURRENT CUSTOMS BASED ON OBSERVATIONS OF THE SKY; TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF SCIENCES RANGING FROM AGRONOMY TO ASTRONOMY; TO ARTISTIC AND CULTURAL ICONS INCLUDING MUSIC (HOLST'S "THE PLANETS") AND PAINTING (VAN GOGH'S STARRY NIGHT); TO FICTION, NON-FICTION AND CHILDREN'S LITERATURE ("A WRINKLE IN TIME", "PACKING FOR MARS", "GOODNIGHT, MOON"). WHILE OUR CULTURES AND LANDSCAPES MAY VARY, THE SKY ABOVE US UNITES US ALL AND FINDS EXPRESSION IN MANY FORMS. OUR VISION FOR THIS PROJECT IS THAT CHILDREN AGES 3-10 AND THEIR ADULT CAREGIVERS WILL GAIN AN APPRECIATION FOR CELESTIAL OBJECTS AND PHENOMENA VISIBLE TO THEM AS A FOUNDATION FOR UNDERSTANDING OF EARTH AND SPACE SCIENCE (EARTH SCIENCE, ASTROPHYSICS, HELIOPHYSICS AND PLANETARY SCIENCE). ALL OUR SKY RESOURCES AND ACTIVITIES WILL BE DESIGNED TO ENACT THIS VISION, AND TO: 1) SERVE A DIVERSE RANGE OF AUDIENCES, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON URBAN AND LOW-INCOME CHILDREN AND FAMILIES WHO ARE MOST IN NEED OF HIGH- QUALITY STEM ENGAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES; 2) INCREASE APPRECIATION AMONG DIVERSE ADULTS AND CHILDREN OF THE SKY AS A VAST SOURCE OF INSPIRATION AND WONDER, AND AS AN ACCESSIBLE SCIENCE LEARNING RESOURCE; 3) DEVELOP FOUNDATIONAL STEM SKILLS IN CHILDREN; 4) ENCOURAGE ADULTS TO ENGAGE IN AND GUIDE ESS LEARNING EXPERIENCES WITH THEIR CHILDREN; 5) INSPIRE PRACTICAL APPLICATION OF STEM SKILLS BY CHILDREN AND ADULTS AS THEY EXPLORE CELESTIAL OBJECTS TOGETHER IN THEIR EVERYDAY LIVES; AND 6) EXPAND THE CAPACITY OF MUSEUM STAFF AND OUT-OF-SCHOOL TIME (OST) EDUCATORS TO ENGAGE FAMILIES IN LEARNING STEM SKILLS THROUGH EARTH AND SPACE SCIENCE EXPLORATION. PRINCIPAL OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT TO ACHIEVE THESE GOALS INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF: 7) EIGHTEEN INTERDISCIPLINARY MUSEUM PROGRAMS THAT BRING ATTENTION TO PHENOMENA IN THE SKY, AND PROVIDE MULTIPLE ENTRY POINTS TO SCIENCE LEARNING FOR OUR DIVERSE AUDIENCE; 8) FIVE NEW ESS-FOCUSED ACTIVITIES FOR THE AWARD-WINNING "BEYOND THE CHALKBOARD" OUT-OF-SCHOOL TIME CURRICULUM THAT WILL REACH HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS OF CHILDREN AROUND THE WORLD; 9) 5,000 TAKE-HOME SCIENCE KITS TO BE DISTRIBUTED TO FAMILIES AND SCHOOL GROUPS VISITING BCM, WHICH WILL ENCOURAGE AT-HOME INVESTIGATIONS OF SCIENCE BY FAMILIES; AND 10) AN INTERACTIVE THEATER PRODUCTION FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES CENTERED ON EARTH AND SPACE SCIENCE, WHICH WILL REACH OVER 30,000 CHILDREN AND ADULTS OVER THE COURSE OF THE GRANT. THE METHODOLOGY PROPOSED FOR OUR SKY IS SUPPORTED BY RECENT RESEARCH AND EDUCATION THEORY, MOST NOTABLY THE CONCEPTS OF LIFE-LONG, LIFE-WIDE AND LIFE-DEEP LEARNING PUT FORTH BY THE NATIONAL RESEARCH COUNCIL IN LEARNING SCIENCE IN INFORMAL ENVIRONMENTS (BELL ET AL. 2009). OUR SKY EMBRACES THIS APPROACH BY PROVIDING RESOURCES THAT: SPEAK TO OR APPEAL TO A WIDE RANGE OF AGES; CAN BE USED IN A VARIETY OF CONTEXTS; AND ADDRESS A RANGE OF BELIEFS, IDEOLOGIES, AND VALUES WHILE OFFERING A DIVERSITY OF CONTENT THAT APPEALS (AND PROVIDES ENTRY POINTS FOR) AS MANY PEOPLE AS POSSIBLE.
MODIFICATION TO CONTRACT NUMBER GS-01P-10-BW-C-0044 TO INCORPORATE PRESIDENTIAL MEMO ON RESPONSIBLE ANTIBIOTIC-USE.

doc.ContractDescription: PREDICTIONS OF WARMING ACROSS ANTARCTICA IN COMING DECADES DEMAND A DETAILED UNDERSTANDING OF SURFACE MELT INTENSITY, ITS LONGER-TERM TEMPORAL VARIABILITY, AND ITS DRIVING MECHANISMS. ALTHOUGH PASSIVE MICROWAVE SATELLITES DOCUMENT OVER 30 YEARS OF ANTARCTIC SNOWMELT PRESENCE/ABSENCE, ONLY RECENTLY THROUGH MODELING AND RADAR REMOTE SENSING EFFORTS HAS A MORE QUANTITATIVE UNDERSTANDING OF ANTARCTIC MELT INTENSITY (I.E., WATER PRODUCTION) BECOME CLEARER. IMPORTANT QUESTIONS REMAIN IN DOCUMENTING MELT INTENSITY USING REMOTE SENSING AS WELL AS DECIPHERING INFORMATION PROVIDED BY DIFFERENT SATELLITE SENSORS. FURTHERMORE, ALTHOUGH WELL DOCUMENTED DURING THE SATELLITE ERA, THE LONGER-TERM CLIMATOLOGICAL CONTEXT OF SNOWMELT AND ITS ATMOSPHERIC AND OCEANIC DRIVERS REMAIN LARGELY UNKNOWN. PREDICTION OF THE FUTURE EVOLUTION OF ANTARCTIC SNOWMELT, AND ULTIMATELY ANTARCTIC SEA LEVEL CONTRIBUTIONS, REQUIRES A COMPREHENSIVE UNDERSTANDING OF THESE CRITICAL KNOWLEDGE GAPS. OBJECTIVE 1 SEEKS TO FURTHER DEVELOP AND EVALUATE A QUIKSCAT-BASED SURFACE MELT INTENSITY ALGORITHM. WE HAVE PREVIOUSLY DEMONSTRATED QUIKSCAT IS CAPABLE OF DOCUMENTING AT MINIMUM RELATIVE VARIATIONS IN MELT INTENSITY DUE TO THE STRONG CORRELATION BETWEEN BACKSCATTER REDUCTIONS AND POSITIVE AIR TEMPERATURES. DIRECT COMPARISON OF QUIKSCAT TO RECORDS OF ACTUAL MELT PRODUCTION WILL ELUCIDATE ITS POTENTIAL FOR QUANTITATIVE MELT PRODUCTION MAPPING (I.E., MM MELT). TWO DATASETS INCLUDING FULL OVERLAP WITH QUIKSCAT PROVIDE DAILY MEASURES OF MELTWATER PRODUCTION AND RESIDUAL SNOWPACK LIQUID WATER AND WILL BE COMPARED TO QUIKSCAT-BASED MELT INTENSITY DATA. THE FIRST DATASET USES ENERGY BALANCE OBSERVATIONS AT NEUMAYER STATION TO MODEL MELTING. THE SECOND DATASET SPANS THE ENTIRE CONTINENT USING THE REGIONAL ATMOSPHERIC CIRCULATION MODEL (RACMO). A THIRD, BINARY MELT DATASET FROM PASSIVE MICROWAVE SATELLITES ALLOWS FOR A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF DIVERGENCES IN MELT DETECTED BY DIFFERENT METHODS. THIS ANALYSIS WILL STRENGTHEN OUR KNOWLEDGE OF ANTARCTIC SURFACE MELTING AND ITS REPRESENTATION IN REMOTELY SENSED MEASUREMENTS. OBJECTIVE 2 SEEKS TO PLACE SATELLITE ERA SURFACE MELTING OBSERVATIONS IN A LONGER-TERM (1948-2009) CLIMATOLOGICAL CONTEXT. THIS TECHNIQUE RELIES ON THE CLOSE CORRELATION BETWEEN SUMMER AIR TEMPERATURES AND MELTING, AS IS WELL DOCUMENTED ACROSS ANTARCTICA. FOLLOWING DEMONSTRATED METHODS IN THE ARCTIC, CORRELATIONS WILL BE EXAMINED BETWEEN REGIONAL AND ICE SHELF SPECIFIC MELTING METRICS FROM QUIKSCAT AND AIR TEMPERATURE FROM THE NCEP-NCAR REANALYSIS. WHERE SIGNIFICANT MELT-TEMPERATURE CORRELATIONS EXIST, WE WILL BE ABLE TO USE TEMPERATURES IN THE NCEP-NCAR REANALYSIS TO EMPIRICALLY MODEL HISTORICAL VARIATIONS IN ANTARCTIC SURFACE MELTING BACK TO 1948. THIS OBJECTIVE WILL PERMIT A LONGER-TERM CONTEXTUALIZATION OF QUIKSCAT MELT RECORDS AND FOSTER MORE INFORMED MODELING OF THE FUTURE EVOLUTION OF ANTARCTIC MELTING. OBJECTIVE 3 WILL IDENTIFY KEY ATMOSPHERIC AND OCEANIC DRIVERS OF ANTARCTIC SURFACE MELTING. A GROWING BODY OF LITERATURE DOCUMENTS STRONG LINKS BETWEEN ANTARCTIC ICE, OCEAN, AND ATMOSPHERE PROCESSES. THIS WORK WILL EXPLORE HOW THESE PROCESSES AFFECT ICE SHEET SURFACE MELTING DOCUMENTED VIA REMOTE SENSING. ATMOSPHERIC DATA INCLUDING WINDS, SEA LEVEL PRESSURE, AND TEMPERATURE WILL BE OBTAINED FROM THE NCEP-NCAR/DOE REANALYSES. SEA SURFACE CONDITIONS INCLUDING SEA ICE CONCENTRATIONS AND SEA SURFACE TEMPERATURES ARE DOCUMENTED USING REMOTE SENSING. TO DEDUCE CAUSAL LINKS, THIS OBJECTIVE WILL EXAMINE CORRELATIONS BETWEEN REGIONALLY AVERAGED SEA SURFACE, ATMOSPHERIC, AND SURFACE MELTING ACROSS THE ADJACENT ICE SHELVES AND ICE SHEET. THIS ANALYSIS WILL PROVIDE A MORE THOROUGH UNDERSTANDING OF HOW SURFACE MELTING IS LINKED TO THE BROADER CLIMATE SYSTEM AND THEREFORE HOW MELT MAY RESPOND TO FUTURE CLIMATE SCENARIOS.
